metadata.aiReasoning: The content primarily involves a visual representation using a tape diagram instead of a traditional Cartesian coordinate plane. Therefore, a coordinatePlane widget type, which supports points and geometric figures, is not directly applicable. However, extracting the diagram onto a coordinate plane for Cartesian understanding could be useful in visualizing and analyzing problems similar to this one, despite the schema not being directly applicable to the available data.

hints.content:
###Strategy

We can find the ratio of distance run to total distance by counting the equal parts of each in the tape diagram.

Then we can create an equivalent ratio by picking a number of meters for each equal part in the diagram to represent a total distance of $30\,\text{m}$.

To make an equivalent ratio, we multiply each part of the ratio by the same number.

###Identify the given ratio

$\goldE{2}+\redE{3}=\purpleD{5}$

Cauã runs $\redE{3\,\text{m}}$ for every $\purpleD{5\,\text{m}}$ of total distance.

###Create an equivalent ratio

If each part represents $\blueE{6\,\text{m}}$, there will be $30\,\text{m}$ of total distance, because $\purpleE{5}\blueE{\times 6} = 30$.

[[☃ image 1]]

If each part represents $\blueE{6\,\text{m}}$, there will be $18\,\text{m}$ of distance run, because $\redE{3}\blueE{\times 6} = 18$.

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths. The first tape has 2 equal parts, each labeled 6. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled Distance walked. The second tape has 3 equal parts of the same size as in the first tape, each labeled 6. A curved bracket below the second tape is labeled Distance run. A curved bracket spanning both tapes is labeled Total distance.

hints.content:
###Solution

The diagram with a part size of $\blueE{6\,\text{m}}$ best shows how far Cauã runs when he goes a total distance of $30\,\text{m}$ on the track.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths. The first tape has 2 equal parts, each labeled 6. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled Distance walked. The second tape has 3 equal parts of the same size as in the first tape, each labeled 6. A curved bracket below the second tape is labeled Distance run.

question.content:
Cauã alternates between walking and running on the track. The diagram shows the ratio of distances Cauã walks to runs.

[[☃ image 1]]

All of the following diagrams represent equivalent ratios.

**Which diagram best shows how far, in $\text{m}$, Cauã runs when he goes a total distance of $30\,\text{m}$ on the track?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of unequal lengths. The first tape has 2 equal parts. A curved bracket above the first tape is labeled Distance walked. The second tape has 3 equal parts of the same size as in the first tape. A curved bracket below the second tape is labeled Distance run.
